dialogues.speaker: MUSIC UP
dialogues.text: We fade into a scene with all the stylistic hallmarks of a CLASSIC DREAM SEQUENCE. A high school on a sprawling, verdant campus. A sign reads WAVERLEY PREP. Shiny sports cars enter and exit the circular drive. A beautiful STUDENT crosses the lawn. Sunglasses disguise her true age-- she might as well be a teenager. She wears a private school uniform (plaid skirt, blouse, and argyle socks) and carries a stack of seemingly random books. We hear only the peaceful chirping of birds, the student’s quiet footsteps, and the distant, muffled conversations of students. Nothing looks quite real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, we hear a bell ringing. Kids quickly to filter into the school. But our student doesn’t seem to know * where to go. She lowers her sunglasses, confused. She * fumbles for a CLASS SCHEDULE. * The girl glances down at her watch, a gaudy, surreal- looking pink Rolex that resembles nothing Rolex has ever made. The ringing is coming from the watch... *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ringing continues, growing more shrill. Reveal a black old-fashioned alarm clock from Restoration Hardware. There’s a half-empty wine glass next to the clock. MAVIS GARY stirs in bed. She’s mid-thirties, blonde, attractive. Though Mavis is clearly an adult, we recognize her as the student from the dream. Mavis smacks the clock with surprising violence, and goes back to sleep. The alarm bell rings again, brutal. Mavis gets up and walks into the bathroom. She’s not * wearing any pants or underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis, now wearing unflattering pajama pants, enters the kitchen. We see an empty whiskey bottle on the kitchen counter, and a few empty wine bottles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bends down and unlatches a dog crate. A small, fluffy DOG appears.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Good morning, Baguette. Baguette jumps, excited. Mavis peels back the foil ona single-serving container of dog food and places it on the floor. She walks away, not particularly invested in the dog's breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, Mavis swats at the air. She jumps. She gyrates her hips. She looks silly. Reveal she’s playing Wii Fit. A BALCONY is visible through a sliding glass door. Baguette is locked outside. He stands on his hind legs, wildly batting at the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis sits on the small steel-girdered balcony in her pajamas. She drinks a can of diet soda. Now Baquette is trapped inside, batting wildly at the other side of the glass. From Mavis’s perch, we see downtown Minneapolis, the Mississippi River, and other converted loft buildings that used to be factories and granaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis sits at her computer. Near the monitor, we see a stack of books, They’re all titled Waverley Prep and numbered as if in a series. We see #4, #27, #128. There’s also a large office binder that says WAVERLEY PREP SERIES BIBLE. Mavis starts up her computer and opens a text document called pieceofshit.word. It’s a work in progress; Mavis appears to be on page 17. The last sentence Mavis has written reads as follows: “Ashby was the undisputed king bee of Waverley Prep.” Mavis stares at the document without enthusiasm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens her Web browser and goes directly to a celebrity gossip website. She scrolls down the page, pausing over each item, staring at the vacant, grinning faces of famous people. She opens another window-- her email. She deletes all the overnight spam. We see a message that reads RE:RE:RE:END OF SERIES. Mavis notices the message, perhaps grimacing a little, but doesn’t open it. She then notices a NEW MESSAGE. The subject line says: “The best thing that ever happened to us” Mavis pauses, then opens the email. We see a large photo of a NEWBORN BABY in a knitted cap that looks like a strawberry. There’s a small block of text beneath. Mavis’s expression is neutral as she reads the message. She closes the window. After a moment, she clicks it open again, re-reading. And re-reading. She reaches for a strand of hair near her ear and begins yanking it in a distracted, obsessive-compulsive way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be ten minutes later. It could be an hour later. Mavis is still in her apartment and still pajama-clad, but now she’s on the phone. She paces, holding her dog as if it’s an object.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Are you busy? Okay. No. Well, I just have one quick thing to tell you. I got, like, a birth announcement. From Buddy. (impatient) Yes, Buddy Slade. Well, Beth actually sent it. (beat) Beth, the wife? She must have done like, a “send all” or something. Like a mass email to everyone in his address book, whether they’re living or dead or even remotely relevant to the situation? One of those. I haven't talked to him in, God, four years? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I’ve only met her once, like at Moon’s thing, so why would I be included on this list? You know? It's like, think. Like, send those things to your actual friends, you know? Jesus. (beat) I guess. The baby looks like just a red...you know how they look. It looks like a fetus from Life Magazine. Yeah, I don’t know. It has a strawberry hat. (beat) Um, a girl, I think? Yeah, a girl. Well, I didn’t see how tall it was or how long or whatever, but it says eight pounds and some ounces. You know, they measure babies in ounces. Like marijuana. (defeated) Yes, that’s all! What, is that not interesting enough for you? All right, no, just kidding. Well, have fun at work. (beat) ‘Bye. Mavis hangs up. Then redials.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Me again. Hi. Are you gonna have lunch today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis and her friend VICKI eat McDonald's in a depressing courtyard behind a Wells Fargo building. VICKI is upholstered in a cheap business suit from the mall. Mavis is sloppily dressed. Vicki gives her the once-over.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: Just FYI, not all of us have cushy joke jobs where we can work from “the home.” Lucky. Vicki’s mouth is full of fries.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (dejected) Yeah. Lucky. See if you like always writing the same crap about the same five teenagers and their amazing wardrobes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: Well, at least they don’t put your name on the cover. This hurts Mavis’s feelings, but she plays it off.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: And aren’t they canceling that shit anyway?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (bristling) Books don’t get “canceled”, Vicki. That’s not the terminology.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: So I put a fake profile up on a dating site today. Just to see what happens.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: This birth announcement thing. Buddy... Vicki won’t let Mavis derail her anecdote.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: I said I was a BBW with “luscious curves.”

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I don’t understand why they would send me something like that.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: I bet I get all black guys.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Listen!

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: (annoyed) What? You’re still talking about Buddy Slade and his wife and their email thing?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. The baby was just born like a month ago. I mean, when you send something that soon, isn’t it just for the inner circle?

dialogues.speaker: MORE
dialogues.text: ( ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not for the ex-girlfriend of the father, who doesn’t even talk to him anymore.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: Buddy’s always been the type to reach out. Remember in school he was so friendly to everyone? Like he would always pick the wheelchair guy for his lab partner and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: My cousin?

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: Yeah, your cousin Mike with the wheelchair. Mavis picks at her food, dejected.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I have a real date tonight. With Peter.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: Peter Pussy Eater with the Rolex? What are we doing? Why are we not more excited?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (flat) I am excited. Vicki’s laugh is a disrespectful honk.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: You’re more worked up about your “soul mate,” Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m not. I just wanted to tell you about something that happened. God, excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: Buddy Slade is not, and never was, all that. He still lives in Mercury, for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: By choice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: Well, I pity the guy. You and me got out of there just in time.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Vicki points with a french fry, her mouth full.

dialogues.speaker: VICKI
dialogues.text: We’re fortunate bitches. She gags violently, reaching for her Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis returns from her lunch with VICKI. She greets Baguette, who jumps at her knees.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Hi, Baguette. She slides the door to the balcony open. Baguette runs onto the tiny balcony. There’s a small patch of Astroturf with a plastic fire hydrant. This functions as Baguette’s bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hurry up. Hurry up. (praising) Good hurry up. Mavis grabs a banana from the kitchen counter. As she peels it, she heads back to her office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis contemplates her computer. Unable to resist, she opens the birth announcement email again. She hits PRINT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis is kneeling in front of the printer. She rips an INK CARTRIDGE out of the bowels of the printer and shakes it in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to herself) Fuck you. Goddamit. She locates a hole in the cartridge and SPITS in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis sits on the balcony, eating her banana and reading the birth announcement. Bands of strange ink colors run across the baby’s face, making it look alternately pink, blue, and yellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A romantic Warehouse District “gastropub”, all exposed brick and oil lamps. This is the kind of place that has quail on the menu and an organic wine list. Mavis walks in, dressed for a date. She has legs for miles, but she tugs uncomfortably on the hem of her minidress. She squints, looking for someone. A guy wearing a suit waves her over to his table. This is PETER, 42, average looks, moderate hair. Mavis heads over to the table.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hello there. He kisses Mavis on the cheek and she responds in kind.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I already ordered us some Malpaques. (explaining) Oysters.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Thank God! She seems to realize how inane her response is immediately.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (lying) Crazy. So busy. Just a ton of stress. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Working a lot, huh? A WAITRESS appears. Mavis addresses her without looking up or offering a greeting.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: It’s pretty nutso. (to waitress) Sparkling water? Not flat, please-- you guys always bring me flat. Anyway. I’m just very busy these days. Working, working, working. Agghh! The waitress disappears.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And you’re still just writing that high school stuff?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Young adult, yeah. “Y.A.” That’s what we call it in the publishing biz. There are other acronyms, too. Peter drinks his beer and clinks Mavis’s glass.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, it’s nice to be dating someone who’s driven.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Ha ha. That’s me, all right.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I tend to date these really young women. You know, they’re more consumed with their social lives and looking good and all that. I always tell them, “Wait a few years. You’re not going to be able to rely on that face forever.” Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Mmhm.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I really see someone like you as more of a peer. Those girls are like...it’s more like I’m a mentor to them. “Peter, help me!

dialogues.speaker: MORE
dialogues.text: ( ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re so smart!” (chuckling) It’s not like I know everything. Mavis suppresses her hostility, kind of.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: That must just annoy you so much. The appetizer has arrived, stealing Peter’s attention. He heaps his plate with oysters, shaking Tabasco onto their slimy innards. He slurps an oyster with gusto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a gray, quiet morning. Mavis opens her eyes. Peter is in bed next to her, his hand splayed across her back to reveal his signature Rolex Submariner. Mavis looks at him. She lifts his arm as if he’s a Mannequin and climbs out of bed. She crosses the room, wearing Peter’s undershirt and a “date night” thong. Mavis opens her too-small closet and pulls out a gigantic suitcase. She unzips it and places it on the bed. She begins folding clothes and placing them in the suitcase. Mavis packs neatly and judiciously, holding up outfits before they make the final cut. Peter sleeps on, oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis, now fully dressed, struggles to get Baguette into a small dog carrier. Finally, she zips up the sides. The carrier wriggles. Mavis throws a few cans of dog food into a large pink Victoria’s Secret shopping bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis places a SPARE KEY next to Peter’s sleeping face on the pillow.  11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the suitcase, the bag, and the dog in tow, Mavis exits, as casually as if she were going to the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis enters an underground parking garage packed with Jettas, Priuses, and other neglected midprice hipstermobiles. She lugs her suitcase, the shopping bag, and Baguette’s carrier. Her MINI Cooper is blocked in by a grid of cars. She tries to squeeze her body through to access the drivers seat, then realizes there’s really no point to that exercise. The car is stuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time has passed. Mavis waits in the vicinity of her car, surrounded by her things. A PARKING ATTENDANT appears, a calloused, slow-moving older man.

dialogues.speaker: PARKING ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Looks like you’re stuck.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (red-faced) Yes. I’m blocked in.

dialogues.speaker: PARKING ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: This is long-term parking. Usually need a little advance notice.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I know. It’s sort of an emergency. It’s a family emergency thing. My father. My father’s dying. The attendant climbs into one of the cars behind Mavis’s MINI and starts the ignition. We can tell by his demeanor that this is going to take a while.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (insincere) I know, I’m the worst. Thank you so, so much.  12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car exits the garage. Mavis is behind the wheel. Baguette is now sitting in her lap, panting eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis drives through downtown Minneapolis, passing strip clubs and convention centers. She pauses to gawk at a huge sex shop. Orange neon winks at her from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis’s car drives down a rural stretch of highway. Factory farms and ruined fields as far as the eye can see. Mavis takes the exit north, toward DULUTH. INT. CAR —- DAY Mavis listens to Britney Spears and rolls down the window. A surprisingly strong blast of wind hits her face, messing her hair. She rolls the window up again. Baguette gnaws on Pemmican beef jerky on the passenger seat. The wrapper is visible on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis pumps gas at a truck stop. A tweaked-out LOT LIZARD in full hooker regalia approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: You got a quarter, five dollars for my baby? This woman makes Mavis nervous.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Because my baby need to eat.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Have you tried breastfeeding? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The hooker stares at Mavis incredulously. She has a gold tooth and a large tattoo across her pancake-like breasts. She looks like the exact opposite of a healthy nursing mother.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My sister’s a lactation coach. Her voice trails off as the woman moves closer. Mavis is unnecessarily firm.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t have anything for you. I’m sorry. The gas pump hiccups to a stop. Mavis withdraws the nozzle and sprays her hand with gasoline. The hooker walks away, mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Yankee bitch.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Did you just call me a yankee? We’re in Minnesota. Northern Minnesota.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis’s car is pulled over to the shoulder of the road. She paces in the gravel while Baguette finds a spot to pee. Baguette pees. Mavis JOGS and LEAPS in place, doing some of her Wii Fit moves even though she’s outside. In the distance, we see the shores of Lake Superior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis is parked, fumbling through crap in her backseat. She flips through an CD booklet until she finds a CD that says “Mad love, Buddy” in black Sharpie. She pops in the CD. A ‘90s alterna-pop song fills the car. It’s “THE CONCEPT” by Teenage Fanclub. Mavis mouths the words and pulls out a ONE-HITTER. She’s already tamped some pot down into the bowl. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: She wears denim wherever she goes. She’s gonna buy a record from the Status Quo, oh yeah.. Mavis lights up contentedly, exhaling as the song crescendos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a typically sad long-term lodging establishment. Mavis parks her car and walks toward the main entrance. She carries Baguette in a bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG GIRL is behind the counter. She wears the requisite business suit, but her hair is bleached blonde and her makeup telegraphs “day shift stripper.”

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK GIRL
dialogues.text: Welcome to Homeway Extended Stay of Greater Duluth. Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I would like to check in. FRONT DESK Girl Do you have a reservation? Mavis is mildly annoyed by this basic question.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: No. The girl recites her spiel as if she’s just learned it.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK GIRL
dialogues.text: (typing) And how long will you be staying with them? (correcting herself) Us.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe just a week or something. It’s a business trip. I’m a lawyer. A patent attorney. (beat) Torts. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The girl peers at Baguette’s bag, which is clearly a dog carrier.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK GIRL
dialogues.text: Is that a dog in your bag?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Nope. Diabetes testing supplies. She’s surprised by her own lie.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK GIRL
dialogues.text: We actually allow small pets with a cleaning deposit.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: In fact, I do have a dog, but he’s in my vehicle. The bag WRIGGLES wildly, betraying Mavis instantly.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK GIRL
dialogues.text: Okay. I’1l put that you have a dog. She keys some information into the computer, eyeing Mavis suspiciously. FRONT DESK GIRL (CONT’D) How many keys do you need? Mavis thinks.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Two, please. She leans over as the girl makes the keys, as if to supervise. The girl rolls her eyes almost imperceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Two...there we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baguette scampers around on the bed. Mavis looks at the clock, then looks at her phone. She sits down on the bed and dials.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (loudly, into phone) Personal. Mercury, Minnesota. Mercury, Minnesota. Slade. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Baguette urinates on the carpet approximately five inches from where Mavis has placed a “puppy pad.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis darts across the pedestrian-unfriendly highway. The only structure we can see is a gas station/convenience store, starkly illuminated in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis runs her finger along the small, dim freezer case. She glances at the TEENAGE BOY behind the counter and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis enters the lobby, eating a pint of Ben and Jerry's “Cherry Garcia” ice cream with a plastic spoon.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK GIRL
dialogues.text: How’s your diabetes? Mavis ignores her, quickly heading for the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis puts down her ice cream and picks up her cell phone again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Mavis is in the tiny bathroom, holding the phone against her ear. She rolls a miniature shampoo bottle around in her free hand.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Hi Buddy. I see this is still your number. This is Mavis. You know, Mavis Gary. Um, what’s up? Ha. How are you? I’m just in town taking care of a real estate thing. I thought we could get together for a drink and catch up. Okay. Call me if you’re up for it. ‘Bye. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She hangs up and looks in the mirror. The cruel fluorescent light fixture buzzes. Mavis takes her two middle fingers and applies pressure to a barely visible zit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis enters the lobby once again, her pace brisk and businesslike. The zit she tried to pop is now an angry red blotch. The front desk girl is gone. Mavis notices this with some relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC UP: Buddy’s MIX TAPE Mavis is back in her car, driving into town. She passes a sign that says: MERCURY CITY LIMITS. As she enters Mercury proper, we can see that it’s a fairly charming place. Suburban houses, a classic Main Street, Mercury Senior High School. (Mavis slows to peek at the latter.) It’s literally a drive down Memory Lane. Only Memory Lane has changed a little.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to herself) They have a Starbucks now. We see a brand new KENTUCKY FRIED CHICKEN/TACO BELL/PIZZA HUT HYBRID.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And a KenTacoHut? She drives on toward a roadside bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Blue Hill is a shitty standalone dive bar. Mavis pauses on the road, looking at the blinking neon sign and the tired cars in the gravel lot. She pulls in anyway. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mavis parks her car. As she turns off the car, her PHONE RINGS and she jumps, groping for it.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (on phone) Hey you. Her voice is soft and relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis walks in, flush with victory. Skynrd plays on the jukebox. The whole scene is tragic. It’s a weeknight. The place is mainly populated with barflies and other sad-looking individuals. Mavis sits down at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Maker's Mark, please. The BARTENDER obliges. Mavis drinks in such a way that we can tell she’s an experienced and enthusiastic drinker. Mavis looks around the bar. MATT FREEHAUF, 36, is watching her from an adjacent barstool. He’s sad-faced and overweight. There’s a STEEL CRUTCH, the permanent kind, leaning against his stool. Mavis glances at him. She looks away and takes a pink compact mirror out of her purse. She opens the mirror and checks herself out. She glances over at Matt again. He’s still staring.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I believe we attended high school together. In fact, we definitely did.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: At the same time?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yes. You’re Mavis Gary?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Mavis Gary-Crane now.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Oh. Congrats on that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Well, I got divorced.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: So it’s just back to Gary, I guess. Has been for a while. I’m sorry, what is your name?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Matt Freehauf. My locker was actually right next to yours. For all of high school. A flash of recognition. Embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Ohhhh! Her eyes wander to the CRUTCH propped against his stool.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course. Matt Freehauf. Matt. Your locker was right there, by mine. (grasping) On the second floor of the school? Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Mm-hm. I was out for most of senior year, though. He taps the crutch, indicating a connection. Mavis smiles, but it’s horribly awkward.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Right, right.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You may remember me as the “hate crime guy?” (off Mavis’s look) Bunch of jocks who thought I was gay jumped me in the woods and hit my legs and dick with a crowbar? It was national news. I mean, until people found out I wasn’t actually gay. Then it wasn’t a hate crime. It was just a fat guy getting his ass kicked. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I do recall that.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I even got my own prayer-a-thon, courtesy of the Lutheran Teen Club. 10 hours of Dear Heavenly Fathers and I can still only walk in circles.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: How’s your dick?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Not good. Mavis nods. The bartender pushes a second Maker’s towards her, and she accepts it with a long, grateful sip. Matt begins talking again, and she cringes. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not like we ran in the same circles, regardless. You were extremely popular, if I recall. You won “Best Hair” in the senior superlatives. And I was, you know, a big theater fag.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: So you were gay.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No. It’s an expression. Theater fag, drama geek.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Well, it’s nice to see you. Mavis taps away at her cell phone idly. Matt’s not ready to end the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What are you even doing in town? I know you’re not one of the losers who stuck around.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Oh. I’m just taking care of this real estate thing. I have some property, so. The lie makes her uncomfortable every time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Aren’t you some kind of teen writer now? I read about it in the Sun. How’d you score that gig?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Talent?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No offense intended. I was just curious. It’s a cool job. Mavis takes another healthy swig from the glass and squints at Matt, suddenly deeming him worthy of honesty.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: My uncle runs the publishing house. A surprised half-smile from Matt, who appreciates straight talk. Mavis downs the rest of her drink as they relax into drunken conversation. MUSIC UP as TIME PASSES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis is obviously drunk. Her body language is sloppy and she shouts over the music. She leans toward Matt conspiratorially.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I love Taylor Swift! She reaches for a BOTTLE of an unfamiliar beverage, which Matt eyes with some alarm. He steadies her arm before she can spill it.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Careful. Mavis points to the bottle instructively. It’s a cheesy brand of alcoholic CIDER.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Hard Jack. See? This is what Buddy Slade drinks! She takes a passionate swig. MATT is confused. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That’s a good, uh, fact. (beat) So are you seeing your family while you’re here?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: My family? Fuck my family!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Okay!

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I don’t have a “good” relationship with my stepfather, right? She makes air quotes around the word good for no reason.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I got married to Allen...Allen is my ex-husband, Allen Crane, the retard of Hennepin County, but anyway. When I got married to Allen, me and my stepfather go out to do our special daddy-daughter dance at the reception. Right? Because he basically raised me, inasmuch as...whatever. And I tell you, my stepfather has always been weird. Around me, and well, just around me. So we go out and this song starts playing, you know (singing) I got sunshiiiine...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (nodding) “My Girl.”

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: And we're dancing at my wedding in a whole circle of people, and I suddenly notice that my stepfather...has...an erection. Matt reels.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That’s dark, Mavis. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Dark indeed. “That’s dark.” I love how you said that. You’re hilarious. She paws Matt’s arm affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Thanks. Mavis has reached for a patch of hair behind her ear. She’s pulling at it compulsively, fingering the roots.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Wanna know why I’m really in town?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (stage-whispering) I can’t tell you here, man.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (stage-whispering back) Okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis and MATT stand in the parking lot near the kitchen entrance. Mavis is SMOKING aggressively. As Matt moves further from the entrance, we can see how much effort it takes for him to walk, even with assistance. MATT leans on his crutch, waiting for Mavis to speak.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m here because I’m still deeply in love with Buddy Slade and I want him back. MATT laughs, assuming this is a joke.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Awesome. Buddy Slade. I’m pretty sure Buddy’s married. With a kid on the way. Mavis takes a drag. She smokes like a twelve-year-old. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: ‘id's ear. (exhales ) The kid’s here. She had the baby. I don’t care though. I have baggage, too.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Wait, are you not joking?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I know people won’t understand, but things like this happen. They do happen. Usually they happen in slow-motion. Like, two people are meant to be together and then they slowly get rid of what’s keeping them apart. They get divorced, they reconfigure. And everyone’s cool with that, right? Society’s okay with that. (rambling) Everyone’s a homewrecker; we just wreck very slowly. Matt can barely follow her drunken rant.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But see, I can’t go slow. I have to tell Buddy now. I don’t have time to play this little game of decency that everyone is so into. (breaking up) You see, Freehauf? I’m 36. I don’t have time. Matt is momentarily speechless. Mavis focuses her attention on trying to light the wrong end of another cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Um, I would advise you...Mavis? Mavis, look at me. Okay. I would advise you to keep all this to yourself. Talk to a therapist or something.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Hey, my friend Kelly is a therapist! My friend Kelly, she’s a therapist at Kaiser Permanente and-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Great. Hey, just don’t call Buddy Slade. Especially not tonight. Mavis sticks her finger into Matt’s chest, aggressively triumphant .

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Well, I already did. I called him, and he called me back. We’re meeting up tomorrow night. She notices a CAB has pulled up and is idling on the curb.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. A cab for me.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah, we called them, remember? (exasperated) Listen, Buddy already has a life. Without you. Mavis begins walking backward toward the car, lecturing to MATT as she stumbles.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: A life? Babies are boring, okay? Buddy’s life is BORING. Boring, boring, boring, boring, boring! She climbs into the cab as MATT watches, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (hanging out the window)

dialogues.speaker: BORING
dialogues.text: The cab sputters off into the night. MATT waves halfheartedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis wakes up, still wearing her clothes from the night before. Her dog is in bed with her. She sits up, her hair plastered across her face. She looks across the room and sees vomit on the floor; it appears that she’d tried to clean it up with a MOTEL towel the night before. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mavis groans. She drinks from a big bottle of water on her bed table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis trudges along the side of the road in the blinding sunlight. She looks terrible. Cars whiz by as Mavis ambles past the KenTacoHut like a hobo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis finally arrives at her destination on foot. Her car is alone in the lot. There’s a letter on her windshield: "Do'nt (sic) Park Here Alnight CITY BOY.” She crumples it up, gets in and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis sits in a high-tech “throne.” Her feet are ina swirling basin of water. The chair vibrates. A young GIRL on her knees buffs Mavis’s feet. She reaches for a pedicure tool.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Please don’t use the callous slicer. No, don’t. Do not. Unsanitary. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A technician applies WAX to Mavis’s eyebrows and rips it off efficiently. Mavis doesn’t flinch. INT. MOTEL ROOM (BATHROOM) - day Mavis SHAVES her legs carefully in the tub. It looks like it’s been a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis applies MAKEUP with a practiced hand and an arsenal of expensive brushes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She coats her face with foundation like a party clown. It looks shockingly natural once blended. As her lips are glossed and her lashes blackened, we see that she’s a truly gorgeous woman. She wraps her hair around a curling iron, enjoying the process of making herself attractive. She pulls back her hair briefly to reveal the pink, balding patch behind her left ear. Her “pulling place.” She smooths it, then makes sure her hair is pushed forward to disguise it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis sits on the bed, staring out the window. Waiting. She looks at the digital beside clock. It says 4:31. She looks back out the window as the sun sinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis drives slowly into Mercury’s modest “downtown.” She’s searching for a new and unfamiliar restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to herself) Champion O’Malley’s... She spots it and pulls over, gripping the steering wheel. INT. CHAMPION O’MALLEY’S —- HAPPY HOUR Champion’s is a slick new SPORTS BAR, flooded with natural light and much more cheerful than the Blue Hill. Mavis is sitting in a polished wood booth. She positions herself so she has a clear view of the door. She cranes her neck ever so slightly. A passing BAR EMPLOYEE plunks down some silverware rolled in a napkin. Mavis recoils tensely.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Oh! No, no! I don’t need silverware! Her voice is a bit too loud. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. Thanks. I wouldn’t mind two Hard Jack ciders, though.

dialogues.speaker: BAR GUY
dialogues.text: I’1l send over your waitress. Mavis nods. She takes out her phone and starts pretending to compose a text message. Reveal the SCREEN of the phone: “jggjsgnkajwhriuawgf”" Mavis glances at the nearest table. A couple of GUYS are eating nachos and watching a basketball game on one of the overhead TVs. One of the guys notices Mavis, but the acknowledgment is minimal. Mavis sits up a little straighter, arching her back. She puts her elbows on the table, thrusting her breasts forward. She ruins the effect by looking down. Then... BUDDY enters the bar, alert but not nervous. He’s an attractive guy in jeans, flannel and a baseball cap. Mavis is pretending to text again. She glances up at Buddy with expert detachment, smiles and waves slightly. Buddy rounds the corner toward Mavis.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Hey you!

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Wow. Great to see you, hon. Buddy and Mavis hug. Over Buddy’s shoulder, we see Mavis’s thrilled face. Her eyes are tightly closed. They separate. Buddy slides into the booth across Mavis. BUDDY (CONT’D) So! This is a midweek surprise.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I know. I was just back in town, taking care of some real estate stuff and I thought... She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: No. It’s great, I’m glad. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There’s a momentary lull.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: How are things in “Jerkury?” Buddy squints, confused, them remembers the old joke.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Jerkury. I haven’t heard that in a while. Jerkury. A WAITRESS appears.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to waitress) Excellent. A couple of Hard Jacks, please!

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Whoa. Hard Jack? I haven’t had one of those since college. The waitress departs.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Oh, me neither, God. But I figured for old times sake.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Honestly, I haven’t been drinking the past few months. Beth’s nursing our girl, so I thought I’d, you know, show some solidarity.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: You knew I had a daughter, right?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: No duh! Everyone knows, the whole gang. Yeah. I got the announcement. Congratulations on that, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: She’s amazing. Mavis laughs lightly; it’s almost a hiccup.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: That must be so great. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: One thing’s for sure about being a parent-- it is never boring! Mavis winces almost imperceptibly, remembering the previous night’s drunken “boring” tirade.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m just working my butt off. Doing my thing in the city.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Right, down there in the “Mini Apple.”

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (shrill) Nobody calls it the “Mini Apple,” Buddy, God! She laughs, slapping his hand. He doesn’t recoil, but he doesn’t respond either.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So are you still at General Mills?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Yup. Ad sales now. Don’t love all the cold-calling, but my dad’s still there, so we have lunch together most days. Buddy notices the WAITRESS preoccupied with another table. BUDDY (CONT’D) Sorry. Hey, I’m just gonna grab those ciders. Save our lady a trip.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Ah. Very chivalrous. Buddy gets up and heads over to the bar. Mavis turns her head in sync with his departing body, staring at him. MUSIC UP: Something dreamy, sexy and worshipful, like “My Sweet Lord” by George Harrison. In slow motion, we see Buddy sidle up to the bar, leaning toward the bartender. Mavis’s gaze-- our gaze-- drifts down his body. Suddenly, Mavis is alive. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He’s just an average suburban dad, but the way Mavis looks at him, he’s the very embodiment of sensuality. His back, softened by years of inactivity. The hang of his “relaxed fit” jeans. The way his thirty-dollar haircut feathers against the nape of his neck. Mavis drinks it all in, lost in a reverie. On Mavis’s face, hopeful and sad at once... Then-- an interruption. MATT Freehauf.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Mavis? He’s standing over her booth, leaning on his crutch. Mavis is not thrilled to see him.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Freehauf. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I work here. I do the books and deal with vendors and other sit- down jobs that won’t tax my twisted, mangled body. And you?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (tightly) Just having a cocktail.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Right. I see Buddy up there procuring a couple of mind- erasers. Not very dignified of you. Mavis refuses to break.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: It was good running into you last night. Nice to see you again. She half-waves as if to dismiss him. Buddy appears with the drinks. He doesn’t seem super- tight with MATT, but he’s friendly and familiar.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Hey, Freehauf, what’s up mang? Matt high-fives him, glancing at Mavis. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hi. Congratulations on the little one.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, our little Chunka-Boo. The adventure begins!

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to Matt) It's crazy to see you here. I mean, in a good way. Thanks for stopping by.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Maybe you should join us?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Ah ha ha ha...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Sadly, I must decline. I’ve got work to do, and it takes me twice as long as an able-bodied man to complete even the simplest task.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Bummer! Mavis sees how Matt uses his disability to make people feel uncomfortable. She might even like it.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I’1l just leave you two to your little Mercury High reunion.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (cheerful) Go Injuns.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: They changed their name to the Indians in ‘99. It was a whole thing with the local Fon du Lac and... (No one is listening) ...-whatever. MATT limps away. Buddy watches him sympathetically and takes a sip from the Hard Jack bottle. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Sucks what happened to Matt. I mean, the poor guy has suffered so much just for being gay. We see Matt PAUSE mid-limp several feet away. His shoulders sag with defeat.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: He’s not actually gay.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Well, whatever. Mercury’s changed a lot since that happened. It’s way less of a hick town.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Well, we have this place. Beats the Blue Hill, right? We have a cool little record store down on Frye Street. Jim Wysocki opened it a few months ago and they’re starting to get some good stuff. And there’s plenty of places to get coffee. (beat) Did you see we got a KenTacoHut?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I did, I did. You got choices now. She laughs, not sure if they’re being ironic or not.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Have you seen your mom and stepdad yet? What’s up with Hedda and Dave these days?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: They’re fantastic. I haven't actually stopped by yet, but I definitely will. Yes, I will stop by Oak Lane. I miss them both. A lot.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: How's, um, Allen? Mavis is taken aback by he query. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Allen is well! He’s fine. (beat) We’re not married anymore, but...

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m...

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: No, but we’re great friends. I’ve got his back, and he’s certainly got mine. Buddy is appreciative of this.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I guess something like that never really goes away.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (quickly) It does go away. It does and it can. But there’s still a warmth there. A mutual respect. Buddy tries a sip of Hard Jack and grimaces at the taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis walks Buddy to his CAR. It’s obvious it hasn’t been a late night. Mavis is still lucid and Buddy is brisk, businesslike.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Sorry I can’t hang out longer, but I’ve got to relieve Beth. She has band practice tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Beth is in a band?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s just something she does with some other moms.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Wow. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Beth’s the drummer.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Oh my God. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Yup. There’s a pretty good rock scene happening here. Actually, Beth’s band playing on Wednesday, right here. He opens his car door and readies himself to climb in.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (desperately) Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I want to see you. More. If Buddy catches her meaning, he doesn’t show it.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I'd be down with hanging out again. How long are you around?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Weeks, possibly. Or a few days. But I am around, and I just don’t want this to be over. Buddy interprets this as nostalgia. His tone is comforting.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: It’s not; it doesn’t have to be. I know I haven’t been the best at staying in touch but I’m always here to talk or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Remember Vicki used to always say you and me were telepathic?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: You mean Vicki Robek? Robotrip? She’s in the “Mini Apple” too, right? How is she doing?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Oh, great. She had a cervical cancer scare, but it turned out to just be HPV. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Cool. So, uh, why don’t you stop by our place for a hang on Wednesday? We’1l have dinner, and then we can all go to Beth’s show.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Oh-- you know, it would be great if you could sign one of those Waverley Prep books for my niece Kendra. She wants to be a writer too.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: My name isn’t actually on the books. I mean, it’s on the title page if you check inside, but I’m basically a ghostwriter.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Still a pretty big deal compared to the rest of us. He starts the car and begins to pull out. Mavis continues to speak to him through the open window. Her voice is a desperate cry.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: See you Wednesday!

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Yup. He drives away. Mavis pretends to walk to her car, but can’t resist looking back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis sits on the motel bed, painting her nails pink. She looks angry. Carefully, she dials her Blackberry.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Mercury, Minnesota. Residence. Freehauf. After a beat, she presses a button on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. MATT’S HOUSE - SAME Matt Freehauf shuffles over to a wall-mounted telephone in a depressing “country” kitchen that looks like it was remodeled in 1989. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hello? Mavis’s tone is sharp, teenage-bitchy.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Is this Matt? Matt’s sister SANDRA lingers near the phone. Sandra Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (annoyed) I got it, Sandra! (to Mavis) Mavis?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. How’d you know?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: The caller ID went (robot voice) Ma-vis Guh-ree.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (flustered) Well, it is me in fact. I just want you to know that what you saw today wasn’t what you think it was.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Oh. You’re not trying to destroy Buddy Slade’s marriage?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I was over-served last night.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You think? Why are you calling? Do you think I’m like the town crier, like I’m going to roam the streets like an old-timey newsboy? (boyish voice)

dialogues.speaker: MORE
dialogues.text: ( ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Hey everyone, Mavis Gary is back and she’s hatching a scheme!”

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: It’s way more complicated than you could possibly know. Buddy and I have years of history between us, and it’s very rich and complex. And well, you can’t rely on what people say when they've been overserved.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Really? I think drunk people tend to tell the truth.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: That’s a cliche. Sandra interrupts Matt, brandishing a bottle of KRAFT RANCH DRESSING.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Don’t open a new ranch until the old one is done. Matt ignores his sister.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You want to drink again tonight? Sandra (still on the dressing) Just so you know.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Are you joking?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I have weed. Sandra opens a pizza box on the counter. She drizzles a liberal quantity of ranch dressing onto the pizza.

dialogues.speaker: 'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings. Matt answers the door. A sheepish Mavis stands on the doorstep. Her makeup, so expertly applied a few hours ago, now looks a bit messy.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Come in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sandra stands in the messy living room sizing up Mavis. Matt waves at her offhandedly.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My sister Sandra. This is her place.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Mavis.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I know. You tutored me for all of freshman year. It’s practically an accusation.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Right!

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I made you Rice Krispies squares that one time, for your birthday. There’s old hurt in Sandra’s eyes. Mavis nods, smiling as if she remembers.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got your locker combination from the vice principal and put them in your locker.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: That was really nice of you.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (to Matt) Don’t be too loud.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We’re going to my room. INT. MATT’S HOUSE (bedroom) - night If the dynamic between Matt and Sandra seemed stunted, Matt’s bedroom is even worse. It looks exactly the way it might have when he was in high school. A twin bed. A record collection. It’s an awkward moment.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: This is my room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Your sister lives with you.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Other way around. (by way of explanation) Independent living isn’t so easy for me. He limps over to an iPod dock.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: She cooks for you and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: She orders Hungry Howie's.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I like Hungry Howie's. MUSIC fills the room. MAVIS (CONT’D) Oh! This is on Buddy’s mix!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Slade made you a mix tape? Maybe he is going to cheat. Mavis sits on Matt’s bed, miserable.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: He didn’t make it too recently.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: The ‘90s. Buddy packs a bowl and offers it to Mavis.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) So you party?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Just pot. When I was away at the U, my first year, I tried acid with some of my Theta sisters. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ran into a gate and came this close to fucking up my brand new nose job. That was it for me and hard drugs.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Your nose looks really different.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: It really doesn’t. They just refined the tip. It’s not visible to anyone who’s not a professional, um, surgeon. Matt takes a huge hit.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It’s visible. Mavis looks at Matt with pity.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m not feeling great. Maybe I’m gonna go back to the Homeway Suites and watch a video.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, no. You should stay. There’s no good “mom n’ pop” video here anyway. Mavis sits up, interested.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: What happened to Crocodile’s?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: The former site of Crocodile Rock Video is now, I believe, a one- hour dry cleaner’s. The guy who owned it--

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (interrupting) The fat black-haired guy.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yes, he and his wife moved to the Twin Cities. And they took all the inventory. VHS, Beta, all the laser discs-- I know because I tried to buy some of it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Once when I was 12 I tried to rent that Susanna Hoffs movie, The All Nighter. Susanna Hoffs, you know, she was in the Bangles and I worshipped her. And that fat guy...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Victor.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: That fat guy, he would not let me have it because it was PG-13 and it had “adult situations.” I was so pissed. I made my mom call and bitch them out. Mavis reaches for the bowl and takes a tiny hit.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (knowing) You were used to getting your way. Mavis’s laugh is brittle.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I never get my way. MATT shrugs, agreeing to disagree. He smokes pot in silence while Mavis braids the shag carpet. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That guy, Victor, he’s dead now. He cannonballed off the Lowry Avenue Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: How original. (off Matt’s look) I mean, because that’s like the official suicide bridge. It’s just not a fresh idea, I don’t know. Matt takes another hit, not disagreeing. MAVIS (CONT’D) And now there’s just, what, a regular video place? Like a chain?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s all horrible Disney Vault kiddie bullshit. They don’t even have a “back room.” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I don’t watch that stuff.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well, what do you watch when you want to get off? Mavis wouldn’t normally answer such a question-- particularly from someone like Matt-- but for some reason, she does.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: High Fidelity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC UP: Something dreamy, noisy, guitar-driven, slow. Mavis and Matt walk into the huge supermarket in slow motion. Their eyes are red. Matt wears the kind of trench coat favored by unpopular teenage boys. They walk up to a FREEZER CASE, a veritable wall of brightly packaged junk. So many choices. Mavis opens the transparent freezer door. White vapor drifts out onto her face, tickling her closed eyes. Matt picks a box of Swanson’s chicken nuggets and a Celeste Pizza for One. Mavis finally decides on a Lean Cuisine. She slides it under her arm and they head down the aisle to a checkout lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet lamplit street lined with trees and clean sidewalks. Crickets chirp. Mavis drives slowly, peering out the window. Matt is in the passenger seat. His voice is stoner-hoarse.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I think this is it. Mavis is chewing blue Bubble Yum. Stoner gum.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You think or you know? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: This is definitely his house. He drives a Jeep Liberty.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: That’s ironic. Right? Because he has no freedom. It’s such a ridiculous, overwrought thing to say, but Matt is so stoned he can’t help but giggle.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You're so fucked up. Mavis looks out at Buddy’s house in the darkness. It’s small, ordinary. But something about the single light emanating from the kitchen feels like home. Mavis is sad. Her voice becomes quiet and dreamy.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Do you see that little light in the kitchen?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Do you think someone’s awake?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Maybe. Maybe someone’s up with uh, that baby. Mavis blows a blue bubble with her gum, surveilling the house.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: The baby, the baby.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: The problem that has no name.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I wish they had those late-night taco trucks here. Or a Korean truck, even.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Everyone here goes to bed at 9. Your hipster food on wheels would go largely uneaten.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Okay. We can go now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. She looks at Matt expectantly, as if she’s forgotten she’s driving.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (reminding her) It’s all you.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Okay. Mavis throws the car into gear and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC UP
dialogues.text: Mavis, wearing her school uniform, peers at a heart- shaped mirror in her locker. She likes what she sees. Turning around, she’s greeted by Buddy, who wears a tie and blazer. There’s a football tucked under his arm. Mavis playfully takes the football from him and chucks it down the hallway. Buddy leans in to kiss Mavis. She reaches up and pulls a CORD that dangles into the frame. It’s randomly one of those EMERGENCY BURN SHOWERS that you see in school science labs. Water pours down on her and BUDDY as a loud scoreboard-style buzzer sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light outside indicates dawn. The digital clock reads 4:00 AM. Mavis is curled up the bed, fully dressed. Her back is to us. There’s a half-empty glass of BOURBON on the bed table. Mavis rolls over, nearly crushing Baguette. She groans. It’s impossible to tell if it’s a groan of pleasure or annoyance. INT. MOTEL BATHROOM —- MORNING Mavis enters, bleary-eyed. She takes the paper hygiene guard off one of the drinking glasses, fills it with tap water, and takes a long drink. She looks awful.  46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis drives up to Mercury Fashion Square, a mall that has seen better days. She sings a retro commercial to herself.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (singing) Mercury Fashion Square. You can find great fashions there. On 27th and Highway 4... Mavis pulls into a parking spot. (Those who are paying close attention may notice that she’s in designated “STORK PARKING” for expectant and new mothers only. It’s either an act of defiance or obliviousness. )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis shops in the mall’s flagship department store. It’s not exactly Barney’s New York. Mavis flips through a rack of clothes. A SALES LADY, conservative, forties, approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: SALES LADY
dialogues.text: Can I help you find something?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Sure. I’ve not having a ton of luck.

dialogues.speaker: SALES LADY
dialogues.text: Is this something for work?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: No, it’s for a special occasion. Not a formal occasion. Something chic and clean, but also a little bit edgy.

dialogues.speaker: SALES LADY
dialogues.text: Okay. We have some adorable new dresses that just came in.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Do you carry Marc Jacobs?

dialogues.speaker: SALES LADY
dialogues.text: I don’t think we have that one. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Do you have Imitation of Christ?

dialogues.speaker: SALESLADY
dialogues.text: (flat) No.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m going to a rock concert with an old flame, and I think there’s a chance we may reconnect. The sales lady smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SALESLADY
dialogues.text: Get it girl! You want to show him what he’s been missing.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: He’s seen me recently, so he knows. But this is the first time his wife is seeing me. She doesn’t know what’s compelling her to say these things. But she’s saying them as candidly as if she were in therapy.

dialogues.speaker: SALESLADY
dialogues.text: Well. It’s the end of my shift, and my son needs to be picked up at school, so I’m just going to send over another associate. Okay? She’s up on all the trends. I’m sure you’ll find something.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: SALESLADY
dialogues.text: (hurrying away) Shawna? Can you help this lady out? INT. MAVIS’S CAR - DAY Mavis pulls up to the curb near Buddy’s house. She’s wearing a simple white camisole, a pencil skirt and wedges. She looks good.  48. EXT. BUDDY’S HOUSE - DAY Buddy’s house is a modest one-story with a large porch. An old car is parked in the driveway. Everything is solidly lower middle class. Buddy is on the porch with his wife BETH and their tiny BABY. He waves. Mavis walks up to the porch.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: What’s uuuuup? He subtly flashes fake gang signs.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Hi. Beth rises and takes off her Wayfarers. She’s a pretty woman, still carrying some baby weight around her breasts and middle. She has a kind smile and wears a rock T-shirt with corduroys and Converse.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Hi. Nice to see you again. She hugs Mavis lightly.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You too.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you guys met before.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Once, at a party a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (to Buddy) Remember New Years in Dinkytown? Moon’s old place?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, wow. Can I get you something to drink? Beer?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I don’t really drink much alcohol. Maybe just a sparkling water or something. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shrugging at her odd request, Buddy gets up to fetch the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I’1l see what I can do. He heads into the house, calling back at them. BUDDY (CONT’D) Meet the baby! Mavis smiles at the baby uncomfortably. Beth casually lifts up her shirt to nurse.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Pardon me. We’re always eating around here.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I can see that. The baby roots and latches on to Beth’s breast. Mavis watches, feeling uptight and pristine in her camisole.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My sister is a lactation coach.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (friendly) Yeah? That’s a neat job. The baby suckles noisily. Beth gazes at her daughter tenderly. Mavis touches the baby’s head almost dutifully.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: She's really cute.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: She’s like a clone of Buddy. You should see his baby pictures next to her. She got the Slade nose, the Slade everything.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: All of it.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Yes. Mavis examines the baby’s face.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: No. She didn’t. I can see you in there. A lot of you, in fact. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beth leans over and calls to Buddy through the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Can you bring me a Summer Ale? Mavis looks taken aback. Beth laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s fine, I can just pump and dump after the show. Don’t worry, I’m not trying to get my kid hammered.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I know, it just seemed funny.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: So, how are you? I know you’re a author. I saw that cool article about you in the Sun.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, I write for a young adult series. It’s extremely popular. Buddy emerges from the house.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: You guys wanna come in? It’s getting kind of cool out here. Beth stands up, still nursing the baby.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Sure, babe. INT. BUDDY’S HOUSE - SAME They enter the house. It’s modest, but warm and artsy. Beth places the baby in an aquarium-themed contraption with flashing lights and dangling seashells.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: That’s pretty fancy.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Ah yes, the Funquarium. Always chills her out. (to baby) Yes! You love it. (back to Mavis) We’re starting to get smiles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Buddy hands Beth a beer.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Here you go, babe. Beth hands Mavis a plain bottle of water.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: How's this?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Thanks. They sit down on a hipster flea market couch.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like your day-cor, what is this, Regency?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Goodwill.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Me and Buddy used to go thrifting all the time. We had a huge stupid T-shirt collection. Just the dumbest things.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Yes, I used to sleep in Buddy's shirts. And boxers.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Heh. Mavis pushes it a little further, addressing Beth.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I still have a few, I think. Buddy looks uncomfortable, but Beth smiles broadly. Mavis sees a strange CHART leaning against the wall. It shows cartoon faces with different expressions. One says “HAPPY,” one says “SAD” and so on.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s that chart?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Beth teaches special needs kids. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Ahhh!

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: A lot of my kids learn emotions cognitively. It doesn’t come naturally to them the way it does for you or me. So we need to show them: This is what happy looks like. This is what anxious looks like. And so on. Mavis is fascinated with the chart.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: How about, like, neutral? What if you don’t feel anything?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: That’s kind of how they are a lot of the time, so. Yeah. Don’t need to teach it. Buddy changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Mavis, tell us about your life in the big city.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I feel incredibly free. I can come and go as I please. Nightlife, brunch. I’m never home. Never.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: No pets? 52. Mavis seems to suddenly, guiltily remember Baguette.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Mm. I do have a dog.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Oh. Nice.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: But he’s small, he goes everywhere, with me. Dogs are so easy. You can still have a life, you know? Beth is watching the baby fondly. Her loving expression negates everything Mavis is insinuating. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mavis takes a drink of ice water and looks longingly at Buddy. She crosses her long, bare legs. There’s a bead of water on her lip, which she wipes away. Buddy is beginning to sense something isn’t right.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Beth, when did you have this baby?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Two weeks and two days.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Well. You’re really getting your figure back. This is the last thing Beth cares about, but she is gracious.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Thanks. Uncomfortable silence fills the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby sleeps in a car seat contraption. Buddy, Mavis and Beth eat burritos from Chipotle. Buddy pats one of the styrofoam take-out containers approvingly.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Chipotle, how ‘bout it?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: What happened to Hungry Howie’s? Isn’t that still your favorite?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I don’t think we’ve ever ordered from there, have we honey?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Well, you are relatively new around here, Beth.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (politely) Um, yeah, I guess I’ve only been here, like...nine years?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Nine years, yup. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Where are you originally from, anyway? Beth swallows and dabs her mouth with a napkin.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Oh. Close by, actually. I grew up in East Duluth.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You were rich.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (taken aback) We weren’t loaded. My dad was a podiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: My father’s a doctor too.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Stepdad. If Mavis is annoyed by the correction, she doesn’t let on.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to Buddy) No, my biological father is also in the medical field.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Where does he practice? Buddy cringes, knowing this is a sore subject.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Beth. I’m afraid I haven’t seen him in years.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Sorry for what? She pats Buddy’s arm. MAVIS (CONT’D) Poor Buddy’s over here like Ahhhh! No, it’s all right. I’ve been dealing with it forever. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks at Buddy meaningfully.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Buddy knows the whole story. He knows everything about me. The whole story of Mavis.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: That is true. Mavis takes a long, satisfying gulp of water, glancing at Beth over the rim of the glass. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (through a mouthful of food) Ooh! Babysitter’s here.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Rock and roll! Buddy springs up and bounds toward the door

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to Beth) This is all very exciting. Do you need to get dressed for the show?

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I am dressed for the show. EXT. CHAMPION 0’ MALLEY’S - EVENING (TO ESTABLISH) There’s a modest line of people outside the bar, mostly in their 30s and 40s. INT. CHAMPION 0’ MALLEY’S - SAME We pan past a HOMEMADE FLYER advertising Beth’s band. It says “Nipple Confusion: Moms That Rock!” The four band members are pictured in a grid, Beatles-style. The band is tuning up on a tiny stage surrounded by brass rails. The lead singer, MARY ELLEN TRANTOWSKI, has tattoos on her arms and a cool (for Duluth) haircut. There’s also a bass player, a guitarist, and of course, Beth. She fusses with her drums, tightening them up with a key. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY ELLEN
dialogues.text: (into mic) Testing! Four-four, three-three... Mavis and Buddy linger by the bar. Mavis is drinking Buddy’s brand of beer. She hands a fresh bottle to Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks, Mavis.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: So are they any good?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Are they good? The band. Buddy seems a little looser than usual. He finishes off the beer.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Totally. Look, Freehauf’s over there. Sure enough, Matt is leaning against an EMPLOYEES ONLY doorway near the rear of the bar. He watches the stage passively, his arms crossed over his belly. Mavis tries to not make eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Ha. God, he’s always just lurking around, isn’t he? So creepy!

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Matt’s been through a lot. He’s a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Well, he freaks me out. Look at his face. He’s so doughy. He looks like a murderer. It’s a dumb, mean comment but Buddy is amused.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (chuckling) You definitely are a writer Mavis.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: See? Now you’re laughing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: You’ve always been so funny. Mavis is thrilled with this moment of attention and validation. She leans in and opens her mouth to speak. Alas, she’s quickly drowned out by the sound of Beth. doing an EXTREMELY LOUD SOUND CHECK on her drums. BANG! BANG! BANG! BOOM. BOOM. BOOM. The sound guy gives Beth a thumbs-up from his console. Mavis is beyond irritated.

dialogues.speaker: MARY ELLEN
dialogues.text: (onstage) Hello Mercury! The small crowd cheers. MARY ELLEN (CONT’D) I’m Mary Ellen Trantowski and we are Nipple Confusion! Please be kind, as this is only our second show and we all have small children at home. Friendly laughter from the crowd. MARY ELLEN (CONT’D) This first one is a cover. It was originally recorded by Teenage Fanclub in 1996. It was our drummer Beth’s idea. She gestures to Beth, who grins and waves a drum stick and Buddy and Mavis’s direction. Buddy leans toward Mavis instructively and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Beth loves this song. The song begins with a few loud strums and a familiar couplet sung by Mary Beth:

dialogues.speaker: MARY ELLEN
dialogues.text: (singing) She wears denim wherever she goes... Mavis’s face falls as she watches them play. This is HER song with Buddy. The song from the mix tape. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beth pounds the drums with unschooled enthusiasm. Even though the band is technically sloppy, everyone is smiling and cheering. Mavis’s eyes fill up with tears. Or is she just drunk? She looks around. Up front, a PROUD DAD holds a toddler wearing LARGE PROTECTIVE HEADPHONES. Two KIDS, about 7 and 9, dance in front of the stage. The women in the band-- even Beth, who drums doggedly-- HARMONIZE TOGETHER on the chorus, and not very well.

dialogues.speaker: MARY ELLEN
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to hurt you, oh yeah... Mavis looks at Buddy. He’s rocking out, guzzling anouther beer. Mavis glances at Matt Freehauf, who’s still leaning against the doorway. Their eyes meet. His gaze is full of pity. She hates that he pities her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Mavis’s POV, we head toward a pair of double doors. Just outside the doors, we see a group of gossiping GIRLS wearing high-school uniforms. Only they’re not girls; they’re BETH’S FRIENDS. Mary Ellen glances at Mavis through the glass with a sneer. Mavis pushes through the doors.

dialogues.speaker: ABRUPT CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. CHAMPION 0’ MALLEY’S - NIGHT Mavis opens the front door of the bar to exit. It’s a typical postshow scene, albeit a little more family- friendly. The crowd spills out onto the sidewalk. Friends load BAND GEAR into someone’s van. Beth and her bandmates chat excitedly. Beth is clearly having a blast. Mavis and Buddy linger on the periphery.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (laughing) I messed up the fill so bad on “Haircut.” I’m sorry guys.

dialogues.speaker: BASSIST
dialogues.text: No honey, you were great. Buddy’s voice is a loud, drunken bray. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you guys were namazing.

dialogues.speaker: MARY ELLEN
dialogues.text: Did he just say “namazing?” The women titter at Buddy’s mistake.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (affectionate) I think someone’s had a few too many.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Oh, hardly...

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Yup, I’m pretty drunk. Bethie, we gotta get home. Relieve the babysitter. He takes another swill of beer, amid protests from Beth’s rowdy mom-friends.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Aw, really? I want to stay out just a little while longer.

dialogues.speaker: GUITARIST
dialogues.text: Yeah Buddy, you can’t have her back yet! Beth pouts cutely, batting her lashes at Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (suddenly) I’ll drive him home.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (eager ) Really? Mary Ellen gives Mavis the once-over. Mavis notices the coldness of her stare. Beth may be oblivious, but nothing gets past Mary Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: MARY ELLEN
dialogues.text: It’s interesting to see you hanging around again, Mavis. Mavis summons her best high-school bitch attitude. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Mary Ellen, you were great tonight. It’s inspiring to see a single, partnerless mother with so much confidence onstage.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Buddy, let Mavis drive you home, OK? I’m gonna stay and celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Sure. Okay. Mavis takes the Jeep keys from Buddy. She holds them up and clicks the “unlock” button triumphantly.
