As the car BEEPS, Mavis flashes her best shit-eating grin at a scowling Mary Ellen. EXT. BUDDY’S HOUSE - NIGHT (TO ESTABLISH) The Jeep pulls up. Mavis and Buddy get out and walk up onto the porch. Buddy stumbles, leaning on Mavis. We hear their voices in the night.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Easy, Bud.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: My tolerance has really gone down since you knew me.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: What do you mean, “since I knew you”? EXT. BUDDY’S HOUSE (PORCH) - NIGHT (TO ESTABLISH) Buddy goes to enter the house, but Mavis stops him.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Hey, wait.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: What? Mavis takes Buddy by the wrist and looks at his cheap Timex watch. To her, it’s more beautiful than any Rolex. She pushes the “Indiglo” button, illuminating the watch, and shows Buddy the time. 10:53. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (whispering) Look. You still have seven Minutes. Don’t you have that baby- sitter until 11?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. But seven minutes is nothing. We can’t go anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: That’s true. We can’t. But time is so precious. Buddy’s words are slurred.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I know, I know, Mavis. I’m learning that from my little girl. This isn’t what Mavis wants to hear, but it gives her a new tactic.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You’re a great father. You’re already going above and beyond in so many ways. Remember when we were kids? Dads didn’t have to do shit. They came and they went and we still bought them new golf balls and tie tacks on Father’s Day. But you-- you’ve really stepped up to the plate. You do too much, even. Now Buddy’s voice has become similarly low and intimate.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Do you think so?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Yes. You’re such a good, good man, Buddy. Don’t ever shortchange yourself. Buddy chuckles softly and drunkenly. His hand has wandered to Mavis’s bare arm. It’s a friendly grip, more for balance than anything, but there’s tension now.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I just...I really love my daughter. Mavis hugs him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I know. And that’s the only thing that matters. Not Beth, not anything-- Buddy and Mavis’s faces meet in a KISS. It’s a hard close mouthed kiss, but a kiss nonetheless. Buddy pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hey. The BABYSITTER, an effeminate college-aged guy, suddenly opens the door and appears on the porch. He holds a pacifier in one hand and stares daggers at Mavis.

dialogues.speaker: BABYSITTER
dialogues.text: (indignant ) I thought I saw lights.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, um, Daniel. I’m home.

dialogues.speaker: BABYSITTER
dialogues.text: Where’s Beth?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (exaggerating) Beth wanted to stay out all night and party.

dialogues.speaker: BABYSITTER
dialogues.text: Well, we’re all out of breastmilk and she doesn’t want the nuk anymore. He holds up the “nuk,” a pacifier, as if it’s tainted.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I got it. Buddy heads into the house, drunk and flustered, not turning to say goodbye to Mavis.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Good night, Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: BABYSITTER
dialogues.text: (slamming door) Good night.  63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The transition is sudden, but we can immediately see that Mavis and Freehauf are drowning their sorrows again. Mavis is mid-rant.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Fuck! Freehauf is fiddling with the jukebox.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey Matt, know what I hate? Matt. Know what I hate? Water.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: water?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I do, I hate water! Do you know what Frank Sinatra used to say when someone offered him a glass water? He’d go, (doing Frank) “I'm thirsty, not dirty!” Matt punches in some Guns n’ Roses.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Water just tastes. Like. A toilet.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You need to ease up. Okay? You’re drinking every night. Your liver must look like like a State Fair pickle. Mavis has a wet, unlit cigarette between her lips.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m on a bender. This is what people on benders do.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (mocking) Ooh, cool. Punk rock. Taxi Driver. Why are you on a bender, Mavis?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Because I’m depressed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: So? That’s like 70% of the population. Maybe more. Why don’t you exercise or something? Take your fucking dog for a walk for once.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Why don’t you walk, fat ass?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck! Me! Fuuuuck!

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I hate this guy over here. Matt nods toward a MAN in a WHEELCHAIR. The man is drinking a beer and laughing with a group of friends.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (surprised) Ugh. My cousin Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Mike Moran is your cousin?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it’s not like we’re in touch. He’s not even my first cousin. He’s my mom’s cousin.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That’s your cousin over there, whom you’re ignoring?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (annoyed) How often do you see your cousins?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: My cousins all live in Germany. MIKE has spotted them and is wheeling over with a broad grin on his face.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here comes the happiest cripple in Minnesota.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Mavis? What is up, girly-friend? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He holds his arms outstretched. Mavis leans in for a hug.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holy shit, this is such a rad surprise! Mavis is as wooden as Mike is enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m just in town taking care of a real estate thing. And how are you?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’m great. You know, Kim and I just had our six-year anniversary.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Six years, what is that, wood? Porcelain?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hot lead? Mike It’s candy. Hee! Anyway, the kids are great. Work is a trip, but I play hard, too. I’ve been doing a lot of rock-climbing. Matt is incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What, like, rock-crawling, you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Nahh, I’m vertical, bro. Believe it or not. You should try it, Matt. We can do anything a normal can do. Probably more, because we've had to reboot for extra positivity, know what I’m saying?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (dry) ; Yeah, you should try it, Matt.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I love the way this guy talks. He’s like, “no.” I’m so glad you guys are buds, I can totally see it. It’s like Will and Grace.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: It is!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, it isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Look, I’m gonna roll back to my boys, but we should chat later! I‘1l buy you a scotch or whatever you’ve got there. I love this place on Fridays-- it goes off. Mavis hoists her glass. Mike rolls away.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: When did he get that chair? When we were freshmen?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Sophomore homecoming. Car wreck. He got so much attention. She rolls her eyes. Matt laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He did, he practically ruined my Sweet Sixteen. Well, just the family party, but still.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You’re a piece of work.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You’re a dumb piece of shit. MATT loudly clinks Mavis’s stationary glass. Mavis responds in a quieter way: She puts her glass against his and holds it there for a beat, like a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little patch of lawn, wood chips, and modern play equipment near a small lake in Mercury. Kids cavort nearby. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The sun shines on Mavis’s beautiful hair. She looks like a shampoo commercial, albeit with a hangover. She kneels and unzips Baguette’s tiny dog bag.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to passerby) Dogs are okay here, right? Baguette leaps out and runs as fast as his tiny legs will allow. It’s a Born Free moment as he flies across the grass, overjoyed to be out of the Homeway Suites and finally getting some attention. The park is fenced, and he’s good to go. Mavis watches him, pleased. She sits down on a bench and unwraps one of those granola bars that’s marketed to women. She takes out her laptop and opens it. She opens pieceofshit.word and begins typing. Ashby and Isabella had a bond that could not broken. This, everyone knew. However, Isbella could not could not could not Mavis looks up, up checking on the dog.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good, Baguette! Is this fun? It definitely is fun. A MAN walks by and admires the prancing dog.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Someone looks happy to be out. Mavis’s mouth is full of granola bar.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to man) He’s crazy about this park. Mavis’s CELL PHONE rings. It’s Buddy. Oh my God! Mavis stares at the ringing phone as if it’s an oracle.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to herself) Hello. Hello. (warmly ) Hey you! That’s it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (picking up) Hey you!

dialogues.speaker: PHONE CALL
dialogues.text: INT. BUDDY’S HOUSE (KITCHEN) - DAY Close on Buddy, leaning against the wall with a diet soda in his hand. He looks troubled.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Hi, how are you? Mavis seems to interpret this innocent query as something more meaningful.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m good. I’m good. What is it, Bud?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Oh, well, I meant to ask you this on Wednesday. He takes a deep breath, tense. BUDDY (CONT’D) I was just wondering, well if you’re still around, if you’d like to come to the baby’s naming ceremony this weekend. It’s just a little hippie thing we’re doing in our yard. Not religious or anything. It’s non-secular.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Secular.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I would love to come.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Good. Great.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Saturday, our place, around one. Cool? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Okay. Great, Bud. ‘Bye. Mavis hangs up, quietly thrilled. She hops.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ON BUDDY
dialogues.text: Buddy hangs up and turns around. Reveal Beth, wearing the baby in a complicated sling. Her expression is unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis is walking back from the park with Baguette in his bag. Her spirits are high.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to bag) Maybe we’ll go again tomorrow. What do you think? No response from the bag.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good boy. There’s a SILVER LINCOLN SEDAN slowly cruising down the street. After a few beats, we realize it’s tailing Mavis. Mavis doesn’t notice right away, but eventually looks over her shoulder. The car’s halting pace is suspicious. Finally, Mavis stops. The car also stops. Mavis shades her eyes from the sun. Finally, Mavis addresses the driver in an odd tone.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You thought you could get away with this? Mavis shrugs. WOMAN’S VOICE (0.S.) (CONT’D) The gig is up.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You got me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Reveal HEDDA GARY, an attractive older woman in her ‘50s. She squints up at her daughter from the driver’s seat. INT. HEDDA’S CAR — DAY Mavis is now in the passenger seat while Hedda drives. Baguette is sitting comfortably in Hedda’s lap.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: This isn’t a large town. You must have known we were bound to run into each other.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I wasn’t avoiding you. I was planning to call.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: You never come home, and when you do, you hide from me and your dad. Curious behavior.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: David is not my father.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: I said “dad.” We’ve been over the difference. Oh, did you see we got a cupcake bakery?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I saw.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: It's pretty good, at least for around here. Mercury is not known for its pattisseries.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Where are you staying, baby?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: With a friend. You don’t know them. I’m here doing research for one of the books. Watching teenagers. That’s why I was at the park. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: (dubious) Do teenagers play at the park?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Well, tweens, Mom. Tweens are our core demo anyway. Ten through twelve. Or even, like, seven through twelve.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Seven?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Kids are reading sooner because of Twilight and Harry Potter. The literacy rate is through the roof. It’s great. She’s lying like crazy.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: It’s just for a little bit. Don’t argue with me while I’m driving. I still get very nervous. INT. HEDDA AND DAVID’S HOUSE - DAY Mavis walks into her childhood home, already crushed by the psychic weight of the exercise. Hedda is carrying Baguette.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: (shouting) David! Mavis is here, of all people! Mavis’s stepfather, DAVID, emerges from the back of the house. There’s something wild-eyed and unsettling about him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mavis? I can’t believe my eyes!

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Hi David. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He rushes to Mavis and crushes her in a hug. He lifts her off the ground and she grunts with discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How about an Underdog? Hedda claps her hands with delight.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: The Mavey & Davey Show is back on the air.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (nervous laughter) Limited engagement. David studies her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Now, you do not look well at all. Your figure looks lovely, but you look peaked.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m an alcoholic.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: (to David) Her hair looks incredible.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Let me check... He leans in as if to inspect it. Mavis cringes. David reaches for a lock of Mavis’s hair and smells it. Her disgust is almost imperceptible, but it’s there.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yep. Still smells like lilies.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Always, since she was little it’s had that sweet smell. Except when you got skunked, Mavis!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: And I gave her my famous tomato soup shampoo a la Dave. Right in the garage. Hedda clucks, remembering. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: (to Mavis) Boy, you were a real beast that day.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I was 13 and in my underwear and my stepfather was pouring soup on my head. My new stepfather. Even while I was screaming and begging him not too. She directs this at Hedda, not David.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Let me see what we have in the kitchen. There’s some white wine...

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I want you guys to know up front that I can’t stay long. I’m ona deadline.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We’re busy too, honey.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: I’m painting the sun porch.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Just the trim.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: It’s important for women my age to do weight-bearing exercise.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: How is that weight-bearing?

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Oh. You won’t believe who I saw the other day!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (interjecting) Buddy, your former beau.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Oh, let me for once. (to Mavis) He has a little one now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She seems to delight in revealing this information, knowing it will bother Mavis.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I know. I’ve know for ages. We’re still quite close.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: You must be jealous as hell. Davis chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We know you. Hedda taps Mavis playfully, but firmly.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: You can’t hide from us, Pee Pee. We’re you’re permanent best friends.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We know you better than anyone.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m not jealous at all. Buddy is one of my favorite people I’ve ever known. He’s very dear to me. And the baby is part of him, so-- I love it too.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Oh, it doesn’t work that way!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: You wish your kids were a part of you. But they never are. Never. They’re more like little parasitic worms. They cling to you and then they inherit the worst of you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Mavis) Well, you have the best of your mother’s looks, that’s for sure.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: I think Buddy will be a very good father. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He always took care of you when you were melting down. Which was-- always! She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (mock-whispering) Or once a month.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: May I be excused for a moment? David has seized Baguette and is holding him high in the air.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Turn on the fan when you’re done.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: See if you like my new reed diffuser. INT. HEDDA AND DAVID’S HOUSE (BEDROOM) - DAY Mavis creeps upstairs and peeks into her old bedroom. It’s the bedroom of a popular girl from the ‘90s-- which seems pretty sad and faded now. Her bulletin board, covered in blue ribbons and certificates, still hangs over the desk. There’s a diploma from the University of Minnesota, and some Kappa Alpha Theta stuff. We see a framed class photo of Mavis with HUGE BANGS sitting in the corner. Teenage Mavis has a smile so huge it’s almost a grimace. There’s a class graduation photo on the wall, one of those giant long-format ones with everyone’s head shot. Mavis walks over to it and scans the names. No sign of Matt. In small type at the bottom of the picture it says: Photos not available: Yun Ng, Matthew Freehauf. Mavis opens the closet. From a pile of old clothes, she retrieves a RED SWEATSHIRT and unfolds it eagerly. We can’t see what’s on the front of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis exits the room. In the hallway, there’s a large WEDDING PICTURE in a silver frame. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mavis in a chic white dress, cuddled up to ALLEN, an average-looking man who seems thrilled to be wedded to her. Allen brandishes a silver CAKE SERVER as if it’s a weapon. This gesture seems to annoy the bride, who glances sidelong at him even as she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis emerges downstairs, stuffing the red sweatshirt into Baguette’s bag.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Can you take down that wedding picture of me and Allen? Hedda is washing some greens in a colander.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Can you take down my wedding picture?

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Just because you got a divorce doesn’t mean that we can’t enjoy the memory of Allen.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Allen’s still alive.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Have you talked to that little nephew of his lately? Perseus or Sophocles or...

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Why would I keep in touch with Allen's nephew?

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Because you were close and it would be a nice thing to do. Mavis says nothing. HEDDA (CONT’D) You shouldn’t have married him if you didn’t want to form lasting relationships. (beart)

dialogues.speaker: MORE
dialogues.text: ( ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HEDDA (CONT’D) I always suspected you married him because just “someone else” got married.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: And I’ve told you a million times you’re wrong. Hedda reaches to smooth Mavis hair. Her hand wanders instinctively underneath, near Mavis’s ear. She feels the bald patch and reacts.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Now what is this? Are we doing this again? Mavis jerks away. David walks in with a basket of small tan eggs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I hope you’re staying for dinner. Freshly laid brown bantam eggs.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Omelettes and a nice, fresh green salad. She smiles, pleased with herself.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Mavis) I didn’t get that henhouse permit for nothing. Mavis looks sick. Hedda heats up a skillet with some butter. She shows Mavis the “Plugra” label proudly.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: (proudly) Plugra. I got this at Anderley’s. This is the best butter there is. The absolute best.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: They use this on the Food Network. David reaches out and cracks the first of the eggs into the skillet. What comes out is definitely NOT OKAY. It’s a bloody mess. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mavis SCREAMS, stumbling away from the stove.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Uh-oh!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jesus, Mavis, it’s just a bad one!

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Get it away! Get it away!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You’re ridiculous. Did you grow up getting all your food at the supermarket?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (shrieking) Yes, you stupid asshole, I did!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Hedda) I can’t take the screaming. I can’t. You ask me what I mean when I talk about the screaming, and this is it, Hedda. Mavis buries her face in an embroidered hand towel. She makes a guttural animal sound.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: All right, let’s not get silly. EXT. MATT’S HOUSE - EVENING Hedda’s car pulls up to the house. Matt is outside smoking. He barely blinks at the sight of Mavis’s arrival. INT. HEDDA’S CAR - SAME

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: This is where you’re staying?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (hurried) Yes. Thanks for the ride. Hedda scrutinizes the semi-dilapidated house (and the semi-dilapidated man smoking in front of it.) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Well, that’s different. Mavis gathers her purse and gives her mother a perfunctory kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I suppose this neighborhood is getting very young.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: ‘Bye, Mom. I’1l call.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA
dialogues.text: Go ahead, lie to me. She offers Mavis her cheek for a kiss. Mavis obliges.

dialogues.speaker: HEDDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (fondly) Peepers. Be well. Mavis gets out of the car. Hedda drives away. Matt stubs out his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: That was my mother. I would prefer if she didn’t know where I’m staying. Matt nods.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (serious) You don’t know what she’s capable of.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I understand. Mavis stands there on the sidewalk, emotionally exhausted. Matt smiles, naturally intuiting her pain. Mavis smiles back, weary.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Wanna go smoke in the woods or something? Matt stands up, with effort.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You holding? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (as if) No.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I got some. Matt reaches for his crutch and moves gingerly down the hill toward Mavis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mercury High is lit up like a brick prison. Past the football and soccer fields, there’s a small wooded area. Mavis and Matt trek through the overgrowth. Mavis shivers in her tank top. She reaches into her purse and takes out the RED SWEATSHIRT she found at her parent’s house. She pulls it on. It’s a traditional high school P.E. shirt. On the front label, there’s a large surname written in Magic Marker: SLADE. Buddy glances at the shirt but doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Our school is so ugly. It looks just like a factory.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It used to be a rubber fabrication plant in the ‘20s.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You know everything. Mavis takes a swig from a flask. She touches a tree trunk fondly.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These woods were like fuck city back in the day. I remember being out here with a few different guys. Naturally, none of them knew what they were doing, but I...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I didn’t know you were a slut.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I wasn't. (cruelly) I was normal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I haven’t been to this place since then. Mavis rests comfortably against a tree, still indulging in high school sex memories.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Me neither. And I don’t particularly miss those days. If I want someone to touch my pussy the wrong way, I’1ll just call my ex- husband...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: This is where I got hurt. Mavis doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Ah. I did know that, I think.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No you didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I knew it was somewhere around here. (awkward) I’m sorry. Is this triggering?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, it’s okay. (beat) Looks different here anyway. I think they cleared away a lot of it when they built that new science building.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: What was it like, when those guys were beating you? I mean, do you mind my asking. Did you say something to set them off?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You want all the dirt, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Oh please, it’s so old. I’m just curious. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, I’m with you every day-- for whatever reason-- and you have your gimp stick and that you get the migraines and all that, so I’m curious. What is it like to get beaten like that?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I don’t really think about it much anymore, Mavis. I’m a pretty positive guy. Not everyone wallows in pain like you do. You practically jerk off to your life’s worst moments. Mavis flinches as if physically injured.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I don’t jerk off to anything. How dare you? Oh my God, Matt, that’s so insensitive. You don’t know what I’ve overcome.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: The heartbreak of split-ends?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Why are you being an asshole all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I might as well catch up. You’ve had a 20-year head start.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I think it’s time for me to go home to Minneapolis. I want to go back to the city. I don’t know why I’m here, I don’t know how I got involved with a married man...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You’re not involved with him! Jesus! It’s sad!

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Oh yeah, Matt, devout husbands and fathers go to bars alone with their ex-girlfriends all the time. They call them privately to invite them to things. They make out with them on the porch.... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He didn’t make out with you. I bet my oma kisses me harder than that at Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You weren’t there. It was really intense and passionate. (pointing) This is his shirt. The giant SLADE on the front of the shirt could not be more obvious.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yes, I noticed. And FYI, you look completely insane wearing it. Look, I don’t know what he’s doing with you, or what you think he’s doing with you, but I do know that whatever it is, it’s not cool, and it’s your fault. And you're shitty for wanting it. Also, and I just want to get this out in the open, Buddy Slade is a moron.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Well, you’re hardly perfect, Matt. All you care about is that some kids jumped you 20 years ago. You lean on that crutch and you lean on people, and you and I both know that you’ve used the whole thing as an excuse to be a failure.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You don’t know anything about what happened to me! Those jocks you used to put out for-- they shattered my legs, they bashed in my skull, they mangled my junk so I have to piss and cum sideways for the rest of my life, and they left me for dead. Things aren’t so great “down south.” I can barely have fuck myself, let alone another person.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You can get past that. You have to move on! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: This, coming from someone who's still trying to get a retake on her senior photo. (beat) Stop seeing Buddy. With his wife, without his wife, doesn’t matter. Stop seeing him in your mind. Just stop. It’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You could care less about right or wrong. You’re just jealous because as it turns out, he might actually want to be with me. Matt laughs angrily.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Getting a guy hot for you is not some blue ribbon accomplishment. Big deal. You’re pretty. And skinny. And frankly, it’s not real unusual for a bored middle aged guy to be flirt with a blonde bitch. You’re a generic fantasy. You’re just a frame in the highlight reel. Mavis’s voice is quieter than usual.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Let’s get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You’re not his soul mate. Beth is. 84. Mavis is walking toward the street. She turns to him with a false not of compassion in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: It's really a shame that you’re like this. If you had a good personality, none of the other stuff would matter to people.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Right, no one would care about my broken body. Sure, people see past that shit every day. Hey, why don’t you use my crutch as a metaphor again? That was really masterful. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should put that in one of your little teenage stories. God knows you don’t know anything about being an adult.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: There’s a reason why you and I can’t be real friends.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Because you're crazy? You haven’t changed at all. I bet you still have an “ugly best friend” who makes you feel better about yourself. Right? (calling after her) I bet you still flirt with any man who will give you the validation you so desperately crave. Mavis walks away, huddled in her sweatshirt. She refuses to show emotion. Matt leans against a tree, tired from standing, and watches her disappear. INT. “KENTACOHUT” - THE NEXT DAY

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC UP
dialogues.text: Mavis sits alone in the gloomy restaurant. She eats a combo platter that showcases the very best of KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis enters the big, chain video store Matt urged her to avoid. The light is fluorescent, sickly. She faces a massive wall of DVDs, surrounded by bright promotional placards and stuffed toys. All 50 DVDs are identical. A sign reads “WE HAVE IT IN STOCK-- GUARANTEED!”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis watches a romantic comedy with John Cusack. She drinks.  86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis wakes up again. Baguette is cradled in her arms like a teddy bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis Skypes semi-successfully with Vicki. Even though she’s just a couple of hours away, Vicki looks as though she’s in Iraq. An AFRICAN-AMERICAN MAN peeks into the chat window, waves hello to Mavis, and kisses Vicki on the cheek. Vicki looks happy. INT. MAVIS’S CAR - DAY Mavis is dolled up in another one of her indie designer dresses. Today is the day of Buddy’s party, and it’s the perfect excuse to look her best. She drives her MINI Cooper into a strip mall parking lot. MUSIC UNDER. END MONTAGE. INT. BABIES R’ US - DAY Mavis walks in, overwhelmed by all the bright, adorable merchandise. She strolls down the aisles, looking lithe and alien next to all the dumpy moms buying breast pumps and onesies. Her high heels clack against the dirty linoleum. She approaches a display of beribboned BURP CLOTHS and looks at them. A YOUNG DAD is shopping nearby. He’s fairly paunchy and average-looking, but he and Mavis exchange smiles. Mavis postures expertly, being cute with him. Her stance is pigeon-toed, her smile is radiant. She’s an incredible flirt. Dad is enchanted. Mavis’s smile lasts a beat too long, and Dad’s begins to fade imperceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis walks to a Barnes & Noble-type mega bookstore.  87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis walks through the Young Adult section. A COLLEGE- AGED MANAGER in an employee polo takes inventory nearby.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to associate) Do you have the Waverley Prep books?

dialogues.speaker: ASSOCIATE
dialogues.text: Yeah, they’ve got their own display table over there. He points to a table heaped with the pastel spines of various Waverley Prep titles.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (pleased) Wow. They must be really popular.

dialogues.speaker: ASSOCIATE
dialogues.text: Actually we just have a lot of surplus stock we're trying to clear out. They were a big thing a couple of years ago, but now they’re ending the series.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Oh! I doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: ASSOCIATE
dialogues.text: Nope, it’s true. We got a letter from the publisher. And the computer says “Do Not Shelve,” SO... Mavis walks over to the table. She sifts through the books until she finds one of her own: Don’t Count on It. The cover art depicts two attractive teenage girls facing each other in a confrontation. The subtitle reads: What Isabella wants, Isabella gets. Below that, the name JANE MACMURRAY in prominent type. Mavis clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to associate) May I borrow your pen? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The associate obliges. Mavis opens the book to the flyleaf and begins to write in an unsubtle way. The associate notices.

dialogues.speaker: ASSOCIATE
dialogues.text: Are you writing in there?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m the author. I’m signing it. The associate still looks concerned that his merchandise is being vandalized. MAVIS (CONT’D) (of fended) I’m buying it, don’t worry.

dialogues.speaker: ASSOCIATE
dialogues.text: You’re Jane MacMurray?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: No. Jane MacMurray created the series, but I wrote the book. I'm Mavis Gary. Crane. See? She points to the flyleaf, which does indeed read: “Story by Jane MacMurray. Written by Mavis Gary-Crane.”

dialogues.speaker: ASSOCIATE
dialogues.text: Do you know Jane MacMurray?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I know her very well. (indignant) I wrote this book.

dialogues.speaker: ASSOCIATE
dialogues.text: Okay. Wow. Mavis turns her attention back to the book. With a shaking, impatient hand, she writes: Dear Kendra. Please enjoy this book. I hope you read other things as well, because one cannot live on Waverley Prep alone. Believe me, if this kind of shit is all that matters to you, you're going to have problems in life. :- ) xoxo Best wishes, Mavis Gary (Crane). She signs her name with a flourish and hands the pen back to the associate.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Would you like a signed copy for the store? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ASSOCIATE
dialogues.text: No, that’s fine. Mavis grabs another book, wielding her pen threateningly.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’1l sign as many as you want. It adds value to your stock.

dialogues.speaker: ASSOCIATE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but when merchandise is signed, we can’t send it back to the publisher.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Why would you send these back to the publisher?!

dialogues.speaker: ASSOCIATE
dialogues.text: Wull...we’re probably not going to sell them. The series is done. Hey... Mavis is rapidly, manically signing another book, making her signature as big as possible. She reaches for another. As the associate moves toward her, she slams it shut, backing away from the table.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Okay. Fine. INT./EXT. BUDDY’S HOUSE - DAY Mavis stands on the porch, holding a baby gift ina decorative bag. She rings the doorbell. Buddy’s mother, JAN answers. She’s in her 60’s and has basically let herself go. Her voice is as coarse as her short hair.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Hi, Jan.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Well! It’s been a very long time since I’ve seen you.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’ve been a busy lady. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: So I hear. Buddy’s been very busy, ha ha! And Bethie. I’m finally a grandma.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m so glad for you. Buddy intercepts at just the right moment.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Hey there. He reaches for Mavis, who hugs him enthusiastically. Mid- hug, Mavis looks at Jan over Buddy’s shoulder. It’s an aggressive, pointed stare. Jan stares back.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I brought a present. She offers the gift bag awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’re just um, burp cloths.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Great, we always need more pukers. Ha ha.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (interjecting) But it’s all1111 worth it.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Hey Mom, I think Beth needs help with the endive thing.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Grandma to the rescue! Jan scurries off to the kitchen. The small house is crowded with friends and relatives. People are spilling out into the yard. DANIEL, the suspicious babysitter from the other night, is socializing across the room. He sees Mavis and gives her the stink eye. She returns the look with her best Pretty Girl Death Stare. Mavis turns her attention back to Buddy, smiling. She reaches into her purse and hands the Waverley Prep book to Buddy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to Buddy) Here’s that book. For Kendra. Your niece. Buddy is grateful, but he barely glances at the book.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Hey, thanks! She’s not here, but I’ll send it to her. Mavis gazes at Buddy, savoring this rare moment of “alone time” even surrounded by chaos.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: There’s a character in this one that I based on you.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (distracted) Hm?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: In the book. I mean, I named him Ashby, but it’s so blatantly you. When you read it, it’1l be obvious.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I hope he’s cool. Mavis laughs nervously.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: We’re not even supposed to do that. We’re supposed to stick to this character bible? But I Managed to slip it through. I had some things I wanted to say to you so I thought I would use the book to-- Mavis realizes Buddy is totally distracted. He’s grabbed a LITTLE BOY and has turned the shrieking child upside- down. The boy’s giggles drown out Mavis.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (playful) Get outta here, Carter-bug! He releases the boy and smiles at Mavis. You were saying?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You must be overwhelmed, Buddy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Because of the party?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Because of all of it.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (not getting it) Yeah. Yeah, totally. It overwhelms me every day, how happy I am.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: But you’re not.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: What? Jan re-enters holding the BABY.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Look who’s up! People immediately crowd around the baby.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Hi, sweet pea. He tenderly takes the baby from Jan, delighting the assembled relatives. Everyone loves a daddy with his baby girl. Mavis watches the “show” as women coo over Buddy’s paternal stylings. She tries to smile, but there’s unmistakable scorn in her eyes. Mavis wanders away toward a folding table that’s been set up as a makeshift bar in the overcrowded room. She pours herself a shot of Jim Beam, checks to see if anyone's looking, and downs it. Swallow. Repeat. In the background, a musical infant toy begins playing “Yankee Doodle.” Jan sings along with it loudly and tunelessly.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (singing) Yankee Doodle came to town, riding Macaroni. You’re my special baby girl, you're a special baby. Hooray!  93. EXT. BUDDY’S YARD - DAY Mavis moves through the yard, now clutching a fruity drink that’s nearly gone. She’s stumbling a little, drinking too fast. Everything looks grotesque. All these pale, simple people, their potato salad and their punch...Mavis is sick. Mary Ellen and some other moms are hanging out near the food. Mary Ellen sees Mavis and murmurs something to the clique. They LAUGH, doing a crappy job of disguising their disdain. Buddy calls for people’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Hey, listen up everyone. Everyone obliges. BUDDY (CONT’D) I have a little surprise for everyone, so if you'll just direct your attention to the garage ina few minutes... Buddy races off mysteriously. Buddy’s mother turns proudly to a matronly FRIEND of hers and begins dishing quietly. The whole conversation is barely audible.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: It's a “push present.” Have you heard of this? It’s a new thing, apparently.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: Push?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: You know, because she pushed out the little one. Jan does a comical little squat to demonstrate.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: Ahhhh! That’s different! The word “different” has a special connotation in Minnesota. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But Mavis isn’t paying attention to this conversation. She wanders in a daze. Her hands are shaking as she reaches for a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Mavis? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I would be if I could get a drink.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: There’s some right here. She reaches for a PITCHER OF PUNCH, but is temporarily distracted by an OLDER RELATIVE.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? Oh no, she’s fine with Grandpa right now. Thank you, Uncle Bob. She turns back toward Mavis and accidentally BUMPS against a party guest. Most of the punch SPLASHES onto the front of Mavis’s minidress. Beth (CONT'D) (stammering) Oh! I’1l get something...

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Oh my God. Fuck you! Fuck you! Beth backs off, blinking. The edge on Mavis’s voice grabs people’s attention. Conversation stops. Mavis laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m just joking, Beth. God, you should see your face. You’re just standing there like a big lump. Beth’s confused half-smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, just kidding. For real, I love your jersey. She tugs on the sleeve of Beth’s loose-fitting, square- shaped dress. It does look a bit like a football jersey. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (chanting softly) Let’s go, Injuns, let’s go. (clap clap) Beth reminds patient.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I'll go get a rag.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You guys sure have a lot of rags around here. Burp cloths, whatever. Hey, use some’a mine that I just bought you. Everyone is staring at Mavis. MAVIS (CONT’D) The funny thing is, I actually could have had this party a long time ago. I mean, this very same party. Buddy and I were together for four years. (nodding toward Jan) Jan knows. Jan looks away, already mortified.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember? We were inseparable, in more ways than one! Ooh, I’m sorry, Jan, Kirk... Buddy got me pregnant. A few embarrassed gasps from the crowd. Beth appears, proffering a rag.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (quietly) You want to clean up, Mavis?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: No, don’t worry. It’s linen. It’s fucked. 95. Beth gently and discreetly tries to towel off Mavis, but Mavis resists, pushing her away.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (loudly) Wait, I’m telling a story. Buddy got me pregnant when I was 20, when we were almost broken up. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MAVIS (CONT’D) And I decided to keep it, are you hearing this? We were going to keep the baby like this-- we were going to have a baby and a naming party and a Funquarium and little fruit hats and all that. And nine weeks in, I had, well, I had Buddy’s miscarriage, which I wouldn't wish for-- to happen to anyone. Even if they totally deserved it. Shocked silence. Beth looks like she wants to die.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe if things had been a little bit more hospitable, you know, down south, in my broken body, Buddy and I would be here right now. With a teenager, and probably even more kids. We always came back to each other. Always. Didn’t we, Jan? The GARAGE DOOR opens noisily. Reveal Buddy’s legs, then Buddy’s entire body, then Buddy’s smiling face. He stands expectantly next to a BRAND NEW DRUM KIT. There’s a jaunty BOW tied to the ride cymbal. Nobody says a word.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: You guys, it’s a new drum kit for Beth. An ELDERLY MAN claps dutifully. A few people join in, but most people are still whispering. Buddy hits the CRASH CYMBAL for emphasis, confused. Beth has tears in her eyes, but manages to croak out a response. Beth Thank you, honey.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? Beth can barely speak. Beth Nothing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mavis is laughing.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: What do you mean, nothing? What’s wrong with you? Are you one of those kids who needs a chart to learn feelings? Why are you covering for me? Stand up for yourself, Beth!

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: That’s enough, Mavis! You’re drunk as a skunk! Beth Mom, it’s okay. Beth moves closer to Mavis, putting her hand on Mavis’s back.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’ve been drunk the whole time I’ve been back and nobody gave a fuck until (indicating Beth) this one got bent out of shape... She stumbles away from Beth. Buddy charges forward and herds her over to the fence, trying to move her away from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (hushed) What the hell are you doing? My wife invited you here. You wouldn’t be here, otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You invited me, Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Beth practically forced me to call you. I mean, she even stood there and supervised to make sure I’d do it. She feels sorry for you. I’ve been trying to blow you off the whole time you've been in town, but Beth is a really good person, you know? And it’s obvious you’ve been having some...mental, uh, sickness, some depression, and you're very lonely and confused. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So she made me invite you even though I knew it would be a mistake. I knew it. Beth has joined Buddy by his side. Her face is creased with worry.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (to Buddy) You're lying. Beth’s voice is low and sad.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: He’s not. Mavis looks at Beth’s face. Her eyes are full of pity and concern. Still sympathetic!

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: What about now? Do you hate me now? I hate you, so it should be easy. What the fuck is wrong with you people? Mavis tries to stagger out of the yard, but accidentally misses the gate.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Mavis.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (departing) I came back for you. For you. And I hate this town. It’s a hick lake town that smells like fish shit. I just want you to know that. Mavis leaves. Someone hands Beth the baby. Beth holds her daughter close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell chimes. Matt limps to the door. Sandra watches America’s Funniest Home Videos in the background. Matt opens the door to reveal Mavis, weeping hysterically. Her dress is covered in punch, and she’s practically incoherent.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I screwed up so bad! I screwed up so bad! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Matt folds Mavis into his arms. Her hair is in her face. As she weeps, she pushes it away, then PULLS viciously at it, her fingers scrambling compuslively over the bare, pink spot behind her ear.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Don’t do that! Sandra is watching, dumbstruck, from her beanbag chair. She’s horrified by the sight of her idol/nemesis ripping at that perfect blonde hair.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Stop! STOP! I love your hair! It’s so beautiful! This is the most emotion Sandra has shown in years.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I got it, Sandra. He grabs Mavis by her arms and guides her to his room as she sobs violently. Mavis throws herself on Matt. He loses his balance and falls onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re scaring me. Mavis weeps, sniffling into Matt’s T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m crazy. And no one loves me.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You're very lovable.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You don’t love me.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Guys like me are born automatically loving women like you. We spend the rest of our lives in reverse, trying to make it stop.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I went to Buddy’s house.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What happened? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mavis starts weeping again. Her eyes are a mess. She bats ineffectually at her face with a mascara-smeared hand.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: My dress is ruined. She reaches down and PULLS OFF her stained dress in one rapid gesture. She’s not wearing a bra, just cotton underwear. Matt shrinks away.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Let me get you a shirt... Mavis kneels there, staring at him, not trying to cover herself up. She sniffles.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I want your shirt. Matt looks down at his Hanes Beefy Tee.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I don’t know if athletic grey is your color. Mavis looks at him, shirtless and helpless. Shaking, Matt removes his shirt and hands it to Mavis. Mavis holds the shirt against her body for a moment, then lays it aside. Matt is not the type of guy who feels comfortable without a shirt. His arms are crossed.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: You hide me. She reaches for Matt. He can’t help but reach back, partially to embrace her, but also so they both feel less naked. They hug tightly, obscuring each other’s bare chests. It’s Matt, surprisingly, who tips Mavis down onto her back. He buries his face into her hair. From underneath, Mavis helps Matt take off his pants. She pulls off his underwear, exposing him completely. Her own underwear are so small they barely count. Neither of them are really moving, but Matt’s in between her legs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They start to rock back and forth. Mavis’s hands rake Matt’s back and bare ass as if they were making love.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MATT’S HOUSE (BEDROOM) - LATER Silence. Room tone. Matt and Mavis are under the covers now, lying next to each other. Matt’s voice comes out in a stunned croak.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Beth’s band is terrible. Mavis shrinks at the mention of Beth.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You heard me. Ter-ee-blay. Mavis ponders this quietly. Then.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: But they’re all mothers. Everyone thinks it’s so admirable.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I suppose it’s admirable to make time for art. But from a technical perspective, they’re absolutely wretched. A moment of silence. Then, Matt leans in, as if telling Mavis an important secret.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I would even say they’re the worst band I’ve ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Really? (long beat) In what way?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well. You know I work at Champion’s so I see a lot of really bad local acts come through. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like a Blues Traveler cover band, except they guy couldn’t play the harmonica. So they had a kazoo. (chuckling) And you know, lots of teenagers who can’t even tune their instruments properly. Hairy chicks who can’t sing. All kinds of untalented people. But Beth's band, they’re the musical nadir. The worst. For sure.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I hate that Mary Ellen girl.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I think she has an E.D. She came in once and ordered three buffalo wings, and asked me how many points they were.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: HA! I knew she was starving herself. She was a parade float in high school.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Anyway, I just wanted you to know.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Okay. She plays it casual, but she’s smiling in the darkness. Matt waits a few moments, but he has a question he can’t keep to himself.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Why Buddy? Mavis’s responds in a sleepy whisper.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: He’s a good man. He’s kind.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Are other guys unkind? Mavis’s voice breaks.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Sometimes. Matt listens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He knew me when I was at my best.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You weren’t your best then, Mavis. I saw you every day. You had this little mirror in your locker. It was shaped like a heart, and you looked at that mirror more than you ever looked at me. And I was at my best. Mavis reaches over and puts her hand on Matt’s face. She looks at him for a long time, widening her eyes exaggeratedly. Staring. They’re nose to nose. Mavis sniffles, but Matt doesn’t pull away.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: (finally) There. INT. MATT’S HOUSE (BEDROOM) - MORNING Mavis wakes up in Matt’s bed. Matt is still asleep. She slips out easily and puts on her soiled dress. INT. MATT’S HOUSE (DOWNSTAIRS) - MORNING Mavis creeps downstairs. Sandra is standing in the kitchen washing dishes before work. She wears nurse’s scrubs and the sides of her permed hair are slicked back into a dated half-ponytail look. A coffee pot percolates on the counter. Sandra turns around and sees Mavis. Sandra’s face is bare and homely. A morning face, on a non-morning person.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Coffee? Sandra nods. Mavis walks into the kitchen and takes two mugs off the counter. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: One says “I HATE MY JOB, BUT I NEED THE $$$.” The other has a kitten on it. She pours coffee into both mugs and pushes one across to Sandra.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: How about some milk?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Okay. Mavis walks to the refrigerator. She pours some milk into Sandra’s cup.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Tell me when.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: That’s good. Mavis leans against the counter, regarding Sandra.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: How are you? Sandra doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me about yourself.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (shy) . I work at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: That’s great.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Do you still write those books?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: No. The series is over. It was cancelled. I’m actually writing the last book right now.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: What happens? INT. MAVIS’S CAR —- MORNING Mavis drives back to the MOTEL in her stained dress.  105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis enters. The room is in shambles. There’s some dog shit in the background. She scoops Baguette into her arms, genuinely feeling horrible for having left him all night.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I’m sorry, I’m sorry. I won’t leave you like this again. Baguette licks her, immediately forgiving like all dogs.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Baguette. I’m sorry. She buries kisses in his fur over and over again. She starts crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis appears with her luggage and dog in tow. The original blonde front desk girl is working.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK GIRL
dialogues.text: Checking out?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Yes. Mavis slides her two key cards onto the desk.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK GIRL
dialogues.text: They don’t need these back. No one ever returns them. You can put them in a scrapbook or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I’m not sentmimental.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK GIRL
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: I don’t have diabetes.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK GIRL
dialogues.text: (of fhanded) Oh. That’s good. You could lose a foot like the guy who cleans our pool. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mavis signs a receipt. FRONT DESK GIRL (CONT’D) If you want one of those donuts, you can have it. Even though you're already checked out. I could let it slide. Sure enough, there are cheap DONUTS piled on a tray in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: MAVIS
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mavis eats a donut as she piles her stuff into the car. INT. MAVIS’S CAR - DAY Mavis drives down the highway, listening to local radio. Baguette sticks his head out the window. INT. ROADSIDE DENNY’S - DAY Mavis sits in a booth and types on her laptop. We read: Yes, Ashby was dead. But Isabella would survive. She’d been accepted to Harvard, after all, and she had her whole life ahead of her. “Life, here I come” Isabella declared. Mavis pauses, then resumes typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car leaves the rolling hills of Northern Minnesota behind as we enter the congested Twin Cities area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A downtown bridge spanning the Mississippi River. A scenic overlook. Mavis sits behind the wheel, expressionless. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mavis gets out of the car and looks out at the river. The overlook is precarious, and she skids on the incline. She stops and returns to the car for a moment. She climbs into the drivers’ seat and pops in Buddy’s MIX CD. Music pours over her as she closes her eyes tightly, sinking into the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ambient CHEERING and crowd noises. It’s a lavish graduation ceremony at the fantasy school. Our blonde STUDENT-- Mavis-- wears a blue graduation cap and gown. She’s accessorised with a tiny gold pin that Says HARVARD. She turns to a friend, mouths, “I’m outta here,” with an arch of her eyebrow, and heads up to the front of the room with queen-bee confidence. As she walks up to fetch her diploma, she smiles like a supermodel. The crowd goes wild with appreciation. Diploma in hand, she reaches up and flicks the cap’s golden tassel from the left side to the right, in the signature rite of passage. The cheers from the audience grow stronger. She gazes out at the crowd. We don’t recognize anyone, until... Buddy appears in the front row. He stands up proudly, his arms filled with flowers. Her face lights up as she recognizes him. He’s always in her dreams, never not there. The applause grows, and grows, and cuts out suddenly. THE END.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH
